On this day 73 years ago, the Allies bravely stormed the beaches of Normandy on #DDay, setting up a momentous victory for freedom during one of the darkest times in recent history. As we pause to remember those brave men and women who valiantly served our country that day, I wanted to share the story of my friend Chauncy Monroe.   I met with him a few weeks ago in Glasgow. Chauncy served in the U.S. Navy aboard LST 279 off the coast of France on June 6, 1944.  His ship crossed the English Channel 37 times to supply the Normandy beachhead. As he told me his story about that day, I couldn‚Äôt help but feel truly inspired by this brave man who risked everything for the sake of his country and our European friends and allies.   With everything that is happening in the world today ‚Äì the recent attacks in the United Kingdom and the continuing threat of terrorism and ISIS in particular ‚Äì we must remember one important thing: Good will ultimately triumph over evil. Chauncy and the brave men and women who fought for our freedom 73 years ago today are all the proof we need.   http://www.glasgowdailytimes.com/news/wwii-vet-gets-visit-from-rep-guthrie/article_5b92a810-4265-11e7-9473-03308a2ea651.html

What‚Äôs one way that Republicans and Democrats can work together to improve health care for Americans? I wrote in Morning Consult about how we can improve the Medicaid waiver process. Currently, states can apply for waivers from longstanding Medicaid provisions to tailor the Medicaid program to their state. Virtually all states use waivers to test pilot programs or enroll patients in managed care or home and community based services.    Unfortunately, waivers often take a long time to be approved. This long, cumbersome process prevents states from using innovative solutions to help patients get the care they need. I believe there is room for Republicans and Democrats to work together to improve this waiver approval system. Read more here: https://morningconsult.com/opinions/time-modernize-medicaids-broken-waiver-process/
